findings.title: RED - Redundant Event Declaration
findings.description: The contract declares certain events in its code. However, these events are not emitted within the contract's functions. As a result, these declared events are redundant and serve no purpose within the contract's current implementation.

findings.title: MEE - Missing Events Emission
findings.description: The contract performs actions and state mutations from external methods that do not result in the emission of events.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract modifies the state of variables without checking if their current value is the same as the one given as an argument, leading to redundant storage writes and unnecessary gas consumption.

findings.title: RCS - Redundant Conditional Statement
findings.description: The contract includes a redundant condition to check if the recipient is not excluded from fees in the context of a buy transaction.

findings.title: RFW - Redundant Fee Wallets
findings.description: The contract declares specific wallet addresses along with their corresponding fee percentages, but the fees collected by the contract are not utilized or transferred to these declared wallets, making their declaration redundant.

findings.title: MAU - Misleading Address Usage
findings.description: The contract contains a mutable `burnWallet` address variable, which may lead to unintended behaviors within the contract's operation due to its inconsistent purpose.

findings.title: RMTF - Redundant Max Transaction Functionality
findings.description: The contract introduces a mapping variable `_isExcludedFromMaxTransactionAmount` and the function `excludeFromMaxTransactionAmount`, but there is no implementation or constraint related to the maximum transaction amount within the contract's transfer function.

findings.title: PAV - Pair Address Validation
findings.description: The `setExchangeAddress` function allows the contract owner to set any arbitrary value without validation to the `isExchangeAddress` mapping, which is supposed to hold Uniswap pair addresses. This lack of validation can lead to unintended behavior, including the potential disruption of the contract's intended functionality.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword, which decreases gas consumption and ensures the value cannot be changed after it has been set.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not adhere to the Solidity style guide, which can lead to decreased readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L05 - Unused State Variable
findings.description: An unused state variable is a state variable that is declared in the contract, but is never used in any of the contract's functions.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can make a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and can also increase the size of the contract and the cost of deploying and interacting with it.

findings.title: L13 - Divide before Multiply Operation
findings.description: Performing divisions before multiplications may cause loss of precision.

findings.title: L17 - Usage of Solidity Assembly
findings.description: Using assembly can be useful for optimizing code, but it can also be error-prone. It's important to carefully test and debug assembly code to ensure that it is correct and does not contain any errors.
